intro: Monogynella, commonly known as the yellow-eyed grass, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Poaceae, which includes grasses, and is characterized by its slender, grass-like appearance. The plant typically grows in wetland habitats, such as marshes and swamps, where it thrives in moist, sandy soils. Monogynella has narrow, linear leaves and produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its botanical features make it an important component of wetland ecosystems, supporting various insect and bird life.
